Salome Magno Soria (applicant) and The Minister of Citizenship and  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> )
Counsel:
H. Alex G. Casuga, for the applicant;
W. Brad Hardstaff, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Casuga Law Office, Calgary, Alberta, for the applicant;
Morris Rosenberg, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Edmonton, Alberta, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.

[1]
Hargrave, Prothonotary
: The Respondent opposes the Applicant's motion for an extension of time within which to serve and file her record. Basic is the submission that the Applicant has not dealt with all of the four elements necessary for a time extension as set out by the Court of Appeal in  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  at 400:
(i) a continuing intention to pursue his or her application;
(ii) that the application has some merit;
(iii) that no prejudice to the respondent arises from the delay; and
(iv) that a reasonable explanation for the delay exists.
These elements should be balanced, with stronger elements carrying weaker elements, the overall objective being that doing justice between the parties: see  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  at 282 (F.C.A.).

[2]
While there may have been some lack of motivation and initiative on the part of the Applicant, I am prepared to imply, from the material, an on-going intent, being the first element of the four-part test.

[3]
There is no apparent prejudice to the Respondent.

[4]
While the material explaining the delay is somewhat thin, in that it does not deal with delay in any detail, I am prepared to accept, as a reason for the delay, an emergency concerning the health of the Applicant's father. Such a reason can be unexpected and thus come within  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (F.C.T.D.) However, as Justice Reed pointed out in Chin, I must take care not to unfair by too easily extending time when other counsel may be doing their work only by pulling out all of the stops in order to meet deadlines and to workmanlike jobs.

[5]
In the present instance there is nothing in the Applicant's material to demonstrate that her case has merit, or that it is an arguable case: see Hennelly (supra) at 401, Grewal (supra) at 277 and  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (F.C.T.D.) at 306, a decision of Mr Justice Muldoon. In Aguiar Mr Justice Muldoon observed that there was, on the material he had, "... just no means of determining what the applicant's case is, or how good it might be on the merits." (page 306). There the Court denied the time extension.

[6]
Counsel for the Respondent emphasizes, in the present instance, that there is no means to measure the merit of the Applicant's case. Indeed, there is a complete lack of evidence in the Applicant's Motion Record to even suggest that the visa officer improperly denied the Applicant's application for permanent residence in Canada.

[7]
Counsel for the Applicant has filed a document called "Reply to Respondent's Motion", which I take it is a response to the argument presented by the Respondent. However, the Applicant's reply does not deal with the merits of the case. The written argument states that "there is an arguable case". Merely to make such a bald statement does not advance the Applicant's position. Here I would refer to  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  Applicant for the time extension deposed that there had been an error in law made by the tribunal and that there was a substantial and arguable case on the merits. Madam Justice Simpson denied the application for a time extension saying, in part:
Without elaboration in the Affidavit or written submissions, this information is not sufficient to suggest the existence of a good case on the merits. Finally, bald allegations of Charter violations without more do not suffice when the onus is on the applicant to show a good case to justify an extension.
Merely averring that an arguable case exist is insufficient by way of an application for a time extension. Given counsel's oversight, a failure to elaborate on the bald statement of the merits of the case, I must consider whether the oversight can be repaired. Ordinarily I would not allow a second try at a time extension, unless there are special circumstances.

[8]
In this instance it is proper to consider whether I ought to allow counsel and Applicant a second run at the extension by way of either supplemental or new material. Here I must balance fairness to counsel for the Respondent, who has put together a reasonable and complete argument in opposition to the motion.

[9]
In doing justice between the parties, the overall objective pointed to by the Court of Appeal  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , I note that, on very flimsy grounds, counsel for the Respondent applied for an extension of time within which to respond to this present motion. Indeed, the Respondent, on that motion, dealt not at all with the elements set out in Hennelly (supra) and particularly the merits of the situation, but merely deposed that material had been forwarded to a paralegal, to work on the file, but the paralegal was away on holiday. While the Order granting the extension does not say so, I rather expect it was granted only because counsel for the Applicant filed a reply setting out that he did not oppose the Respondent's application for a time extension.

[10]
In order to do justice between the parties I should, as I say, balance the equities. The Respondent received a free ride on the last motion, in not having to deal, in any real way or at all, with the elements from Hennelly which the Respondent now says the Applicant must satisfy. It is appropriate in the circumstances that the Applicant have an opportunity to file an amended motion record, including fresh argument and affidavit material, in order to apply the time extension for serving and filing the Applicant's Record.
[End of document]

legal_issues: The requirements for granting an extension of time to file legal documents.
The standard of proof required to demonstrate a continuing intention to pursue a legal claim.
The assessment of prejudice resulting from delays in legal proceedings.
The sufficiency of explanations for delays in fulfilling procedural requirements.
The necessity of demonstrating the underlying merit or arguable basis of a legal claim when seeking procedural relief.
The balance of fairness between parties when considering requests for procedural extensions, particularly in light of prior procedural advantages.
The appropriate level of detail required when asserting the existence of a legal claim or error of law.
factual_background: An applicant, Salome Magno Soria, sought an extension of time to serve and file a record related to an application.
The respondent, The Minister of Citizenship, opposed the time extension request.
The applicant cited a family health emergency as a reason for the delay.
The respondent argued the applicant had not demonstrated the merit of the underlying case.
The applicant submitted a 'Reply to Respondent's Motion', but it did not address the merits of the case.
The respondent previously received a time extension to respond to a motion, with limited justification provided.
The applicant's counsel requested an opportunity to file an amended motion record with additional evidence.

Applicants: An error in law was made by the tribunal.
There is a substantial and arguable case on the merits.
A time extension should be granted to file an amended motion record with fresh argument and affidavit material.
Respondents: The Applicant has not met all four elements required for a time extension as outlined in the Court of Appeal decision in Hennelly (continuing intention to pursue the application, merit of the application, no prejudice from the delay, and a reasonable explanation for the delay).
There is no means to measure the merit of the Applicant's case.
There is a complete lack of evidence to suggest the visa officer improperly denied the Applicant's application.
The Applicant's reply does not address the merits of the case; merely stating there is an arguable case is insufficient.
The Applicant's claim of an error in law lacks sufficient elaboration to demonstrate a good case on the merits.

court_analysis: The court applied the four-part test for extending time established in *Hennelly* (and affirmed by the Court of Appeal), requiring demonstration of a continuing intention to pursue the application, merit, lack of prejudice to the respondent, and a reasonable explanation for the delay.

The court found the applicant demonstrated a continuing intention and a lack of prejudice to the respondent, and was willing to accept the applicant’s father’s health emergency as a reasonable explanation for the delay, while cautioning against overly lenient extensions.

Critically, the court found the applicant failed to demonstrate the merit of the case, noting a complete absence of evidence suggesting improper denial of the visa application and rejecting the applicant’s “arguable case” assertion as insufficient.

The court distinguished cases where applicants detailed errors of law or substantial arguments, citing *Simpson J.*’s decision which required elaboration beyond a ‘bald statement’ of merit, and emphasized the onus on the applicant to demonstrate a good case.

The court considered whether to allow a second opportunity for the applicant to address the merit requirement, balancing fairness to the respondent, who had previously received a lenient extension without fully addressing the *Hennelly* factors.

The court ultimately decided to allow the applicant to file an amended motion record with fresh evidence and argument, reasoning that the respondent had benefitted from a prior extension granted without proper consideration of the *Hennelly* factors, and to achieve overall fairness between the parties.
final_outcome: The Applicant is permitted to file an amended motion record, including fresh argument and affidavit material, in order to re-apply for the time extension for serving and filing the Applicant's Record.
